post_text: Amidst Emergency Remote Learning, COVID, and district shut down last spring, our Advanced Placement students carried on with their online studies and AP tests in May. Recently, Norton City Schools discovered that the amount of testing students who scored at a 3 or better increased by over 12% from our 2019 scores. A 3 on an AP test provides the opportunity for college credit, so it is often a target for our kids. I want to thank The College Board for their tremendous communication, and I also want to thank our teachers for their reliance upon their binders and AP online instructional resources. Most of all...thanks to our kids who "hung in there" during an incredibly challenging academic time and battled in their content-area testing. Great work by all!

Norton High School 2020 graduate Andrew "Jed" Swym has received a scholarship to be used in earning his private pilot rating. This pays $2500 towards airplane rental and an instructor. Along with the scholarship money, Jed was assigned a mentor, David Houpt. Mr Houpt is looking forward to aiding Jed in obtaining this certificate, which is the first step in becoming a pilot. After several hours of flight Jed has exhibited excellent eye hand coordination and understands the rules and regulations that govern aviation in this country.

Jed will have a 1 years membership in ECOPA, East Central Ohio Pilots association. With this he has a resource of many pilots to assist him in becoming a commercial pilot.

We want to thank the ECOPA Educational and & Safety foundation in this task of helping people become pilots. There is a shortage of pilots at this time and a bigger need for more pilots in the coming years.

We'd like to ask you a question today. "Who is (or "one of") your most influential or favorite teachers?" How long does it take to think of a name? Less than 3 seconds for most people. It truly can be an incredible profession because of the teacher/student relationship and the significance of moving through a school year - or years - together.

This week is National Teacher Appreciation Week, so I hope you will consider either thinking about not only thanking a former teacher of yours but also having your current children sending a quick note of thanks to their teachers.

Believe me, the joy of having students in our lives is thanks enough, but I know that there is a deep appreciation when it also comes from our students and families.

Thank you, Panther Families, for all of the support you show our teachers, and thank you, Norton Teachers, for all of the time and effort you provide to our kids and families.

We miss all of you and can't wait to see you all again!

post_text: Thank you for your support of NCS, and we have another amazing student activity to report today. Below is a TomTod group from our Middle School. TomTod is Tomorrow's Ideas Today, and the program encourages students to consider ways to improve their school, their community, etc. It is a student-centered, project-based learning opportunity, and Norton City Schools is the first in Summit County to adopt TomTod. This group presented, this morning, to the mayor, city officials, our school board, mental health facilities, and students and teachers. Their proposal was to add to the existing Columbia Woods Pathway site. They proposed to add mental health stations and exercises as well as benches and gardens to help make the walk a place to fully relax and consider strengths of the world - not weaknesses. This post won't do it justice, because these kids were AMAZING. What a program and what a day for our kids at NMS. We are so proud of all of you.

Congrats to both inductees and their families on a wonderful honor.

Norton Middle School will again be offering a Coding Club that will start Saturdays, beginning January 25, 2020. This is currently an 8th grade opportunity. The camp will run for 10 consecutive Saturdays and those interested are expected to attend each session. Registration information can be found in the Middle School main office and cafeteria. The topics will include:

Computational thinking

Abstraction

Binary Number System

Programming languages (Lightbot, Scratch, Python, and Rasperrian)

Iterative process of programming (create, improve, recreate)

Basic electric circuits (anode, cathode, voltage, amperage, resistance)

Raspberry Pi computer operation

Creating and controlling interfaces with Raspberry Pi, bread boards, and circuitry

Completing a working Raspberry Pi project

Soft skills of communication and teamwork

post_text: Happy Thursday, Panther Nation. Tonight is the district's annual Advanced Placement and College Credit Plus meeting at our high school Performing Arts Center. The goal of the meeting is to provide relevant information to our parents regarding their students' entry into our AP or CCP programs. The chart below represents our district's growth in the College Board's Advanced Placement program. In 2013, we had 33 students enrolled in AP and 39 total tests taken. Last year, we had 85 students enrolled and 162 total tests taken. Part of our discussion tonight will include a school community's push to provide its students with the same academic opportunities that are available to all districts. Please consider challenging your student academically, as there is much research supporting that push. As always, if you have any questions, don't hesitate to ask.
